person_082.name: Jean-JacquesRousseau
person_082.description: Swiss born French philosopher who wrote, among other things, on social inequality and education. His ideas were used widely during the French Revolution.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_236.name: WilliamNicholson
person_236.description: Founding editor of A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts (1797-1814) where Davy published some of his early papers. Part of the Godwin circle.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_270.name: EdwardAsh
person_270.description: Oxford trained physician and a friend of Rumford's whom he met in Italy. An Annual Subscriber to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_271.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
person_271.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

person_325.name: Johann GeorgSulzer
person_325.description: Swiss mathematician who later worked in Berlin on electricity and also translated Hume into German.

person_786.name: JohnLeslie
person_786.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

person_331.name: Christoph HeinrichPfaff
person_331.description: German physician, chemist and physicist who worked on animal electricity alongside Volta and Humboldt. The younger brother of mathematician Johann Friedrich Pfaff.

person_327.name: Giovanni Valentino MattiaFabbroni
person_327.description: Italian naturalist, economist, agronomist and chemist.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_328.name: JohnAbernethy
person_328.description: English surgeon and medical lecturer working in London. FRSL.

person_029.name: ThomasBeddoes
person_029.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

person_159.name: GeorgesCuvier
person_159.description: French naturalist and zoologist who was one of the founders of palaeontology. Perpetual Secretary of the first class of the Institut de France (Académie des Sciences), Davy met him when in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_011.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
person_011.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_1026.name: JohnKing
person_1026.description: Nicholas Johann Koenig, Bristol-based surgeon, painter and linguist, originally from Bern, Switzerland. A friend of Davy's in Bristol, King took his position at the Medical Pneumatic Institute after Davy left for London in 1801. King married Emmeline Egeworth in 1803.

person_333.name: EdwardGibbon
person_333.description: English essayist, historian, and politician. FRSL.

person_771.name: Molière
person_771.description: Born Jean-Baptiste Poquelin, famous French playwright, poet and actor.

person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_124.name: FrancisBacon
person_124.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

person_472.name: FriedrichAccum
person_472.description: German-born chemist who lived mostly in England. Worked at the Royal Institution in its early years, including assisting Davy.

person_382.name: Joseph LouisProust
person_382.description: French analytical chemist. Author of the 1794 paper 'Researches on Prussian Blue', in which he first set down the law of definite proportions, or Proust's law, as it is commonly known.

person_817.name: DeyeuxNicolas
person_817.description: First Pharmacist to the Emperor Napoleon.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

otherwork_064.name: A Journal of Natural Philosophy, Chemistry, and the Arts

otherwork_329.name: Observations sur la physique, sur l'histoire naturelle et sur les arts
otherwork_329.author: Claude Louis Berthollet

otherwork_198.name: Lettre a M. d'Alembert sur les Spectacles
otherwork_198.author: Jean Jacques Rousseau
